_exec_summary.SummaryText:
l project involving propane was also undertaken since the 2023 RMP submittal.  This project was to add additional piping to transfer propane from the Carthage terminal to  a neighboring 3rd party facility.  The addition of this piping increased the volume of propane on-site by approximately 2000 pounds.

No other changes are planned for the propane system.  No changes have occured or are planned  for the butane process. 

As additional opportunities for improvement associated with these processes arise at the Carthage Terminal, they will be evaluated by Magellan Pipeline Company, L.P.

Environmental Protection Agency - Risk Management Plan
Carthage Facility
RMP Executive Summary (April 30, 2024)

DESCRIPTION OF STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES:
The Carthage Facility is a refined product terminal which has been operated under Magellan Pipeline Company, L.P. since September 9, 2004.  The facility stores and distributes petroleum products such as gasoline and diesel.  In addition to petroleum storage, Magellan stores butane onsite for blending into gasoline as well as receives propane via pipeline connection that is subsequently transferred via pipeline to a neighboring 3rd party facility.  Both butane and propane require compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations since the onsite storage is greater than 10,000 lbs for each substance.

The equipment which handles butane includes three pressure vessels and associated piping.   The equipment which handles propane includes a pipeline with associated valving.  Additionally, there is a pressure vessel storing propane.  This propane is used for on-site fuel and operability improvements.  Finally, there is a de-commissioned storage cavern which contains aprroximately 33,000 pounds of stranded propane vapor under nitrogen.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES:
The Carthage Facility has a strong commitment to worker and public safety, along with resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and contractors in design, installation, operations, and maintenance procedures.  If an emergency were to occur, it is the company's policy to notify the Jasper County LEPC and request that they respond to the emergency.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND MAINTENANCE PROGRAM:
The regulated butane and propane processes in the facility are compliant with the fourteen (14) elements of Process Safety Management and other employee training programs, along with operating and maintenance procedures.  The process controls listed in Section 7.4e were chosen based

on whether or not they were used as safeguards in the last PHA for this facility or if they were recommended from the latest PHA and installed prior to the RMP submittal.  There may be other process controls in this facility that were not identified as safeguards in the last PHA.  The facility has no "Trade Secrets".  The facility complies with the Federal and State requirements for leak detection of valves, pumps, and flanges.  Inspections are conducted and documented to ensure the integrity of the regulated equipment.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:
The Carthage Facility has not had an accidental release from either the butane or the propane process during the last 5 years.   

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:
The facility is considered to be a non-responding facility.  The facility maintains a written Emergency Response Plan.  Within the past five years neither the butane storage and blending process nor the propane system has had no accidental releases that have caused offsite impacts provided in the RMP rule.  

In the event of future fire or explosion, or a release of a regulated substance from the butane or propane process, entry within the distance to the specified endpoint may pose a danger to public emergency responders.  Therefore, emergency responders should not enter the area unless directed through the unified or incident command process.  The undersigned certifies that to the best of my knowledge, information, and belief, the information submitted is true, accurate, and complete.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:
As stated in the 5 year RMP submittal in 2023, the Carthage terminal planned to reduce the propane  inventory by idling the cavern.  This project has been completed.   As a result of this project, the quantity of propane on-site has been reduced from  over 22 million pounds to no more than 180,000 pounds.  This RMP submittal is to document the revised worst case and alternative case scenarios based on the completion of this project.
